content.description: The left branch is loose, gritty and scary.  Most of the gear and holds are suspect.  You could toprope the route from the anchors, but it's not worth it.  The right branch may be better.... caveat emptor.

Start from the base of the rock, do a few tricky moves up a large dihedral, and reach a fabulous rest spot.  From here, do some exposed moves over to an overhanging flake.  Crux hand jams and lieback/finger jams lead to easier going and the top.  It is possible to place protection at the crux and climb back down to the great rest stance.
content.location: This is a steep crack on the north face of the rock.

climbs.name: Kleptomania
climbs.fa: (TR) Todd Gordon and Bryn Palmer, February 1987, First lead: Rick Ledesma & Rick Booth, March 1988

content.description:
Follow the bolts to the top. This route is rated 5.10A in the guidebook. We found that going directly up from the second bolt seemed much harder than 5.10A. Traversing out to the nearby arete bypasses this difficulty, and makes the climb only 5.9

Aka "Ride a Wild Oprah".
content.protection: 3 bolts (1/4") and maybe some gear placements
content.location: This is a face climb with three bolts, around the corner and right of Hawks Retreat.

climbs.name: Hawk's Retreat
climbs.fa: Mike Beck and Mike Guardino, December 1982

content.description: This follows a slanting crack on a ramp that steepens to a hand sized crux at the top.
content.protection:
Gear to 3 inches

Use anchors on

Diaper Challenge

to rap off
content.location: Left side of the south face and just left of

content.description: Semi exciting climbing considering the questionable bolts and somewhat loose holds on this.
content.protection:
3 bolts (1/4"), gear to 3 inches

Use anchors on

Diaper Challenge

to rappel
content.location: Just right of the right V Crack.

content.description:
Scramble up boulders to the base of the south face to reach the base of this slightly spicy route which offers technical and continuous moves far from the beaten path.

Pass the 1st bolt where you'll encounter the first of two 5.11 cruxes, continue above with a runout (PG/R) between the 3rd and 4th bolts and another 5.11 crux after the 4th bolt. The climbing eases off as the angle kicks back past the last bolt and leads to a bolted anchor/rap station.

The original hardware has been replaced on this route.
content.location: South face of Hone Dome between ?? and the V Cracks.
